column4: Why does on a new computer Tilda  not show the »Monospace 6« font as wide as on my old computer having the same vertical pixel number and the same display screen height? http:/paste.ubuntu.com/625488
dpi?
If the dpi differ, the font's height would differ. But they do not.
have you compared screenshots at a pixel by pixel level?
No. It is my visual impression. And the difference is so large, that everybody would see it easily.
its possible that xft is doing some width for height stuff to make it look better at that small size and needs to do less of it for one than the other
I will further investigate your suggestion tomorrow.--  Thank you for your suggestion.
xrandr should be able to do that (nvidia doesnt support all xrandr features)
'~$ man xrandr; Xrandr can also be used to set the screen size.' Will be '~$ xrandr --fbmm 332x208' the correct syntax?
sure

My computuer accepted this command. It did not complain. '~$ xdpyinfo' shows now: "screen #0: dimensions: 1680x1050 pixels (332x208 millimeters); resolution 129x128 dots per inch." This is almost what I wanted. Will this setting be permanent for this computer? When will it be effective for GNOME?
you will need to run that on every login or add it to your xsession or gnome-session-properties
i doubt it is mapped to anything as guake likes to install itself to f12
Ok. Thank you.
it means there is a : in the filename
Can you tell me why there is there a colon in the filename?
hm
have you looked at extensions.gnome.org recently. its progressing incredibly rapidly
No. Not yet. I am reporting bugs and will wait for Ubuntu 12.04 Beta.
callbacks are (generally) function pointers called by an event handler to "callback" to the code that bound to the event

in this case poweroff.c is binding to a sysrq event which is handled by a kernel input event handler, and is giving it a function pointer that i is requesting be called when that key combination is pressed
I need a bit time to fully understand your explanation. --  Thank you for your explanation and help.
